title: Escaping bronze while being support main?
body:
I am currently in Bronze 3 and i main Thresh. In my personal opinion i hit 90% of my hooks in my games. Am I able to carry myself out of bronze as a support main? For example, if I main mid and went Zed, i could easily carry my team, whether theres a feeder or not. But support is a different story.   I support the carry, and can't really carry the team. And support is my type of play style. so yaaa
{{champion:412}}

replies.body:
IMO every player is KEY in winning a game. I think you can climb to challenger regardless of role!

Remember two key things about support;

1) Roam mid when you can (great supports not only impact bot lane, but can also win mid lane)
2) Vision control wins games (great supports deny enemy vision and create vision control. Setting up picks, and objective control wins games)

Roaming is difficult tho, because you have to leave your ADC alone.
But yeah Ive managed to pull off some roams.

I find your view admirable and I agree with the ideal, but I also think it's naive and the reality is, not everyone is after the same thing. There are plenty of people who even in ranked are glory hounds who play for the KDA and calling anything is taken as some sort of slight on their intelligence or authoritative rather than purely information.

And I find teams are rarely balanced. Sure the idea is right on paper, but usually it's a completely slam dunk in one direction or the other in the first 5-10 minutes due to 1 guy who is tilt from the beginning and feeds his lane. Or worse yet, some guy who's tilt ends up tilting the guy on your team that is your only hope of winning due to him winning lane really well and they afk or abuse the guy who fed.

Sometimes it happens the other direction, but that's kinda the problem, it really is a random shooting gallery of chance, you either get teamed with that 1 extra person who bleeds tears from all his fingers when people ask him to do something, or the enemy team does, and that's all it takes for a slam dunk to happen.

I've been in so many games where i've carried hard, broken 6 turrets, ganked lanes, team is something like 40/15, and somehow, my teammates have NO idea how to press the advantage, and hang back at towers, let the enemy cs multiple waves of creeps with zero resistance or pressure, and in the end, end up winning the game due to a late game comp/better teamwork. 
You might say "that's good, they had better teamwork so they deserve to advance", really? so the guy who single handedly or the 2 people who really pulled their fingers out and gave their team the chance to win in the first 15 minutes are somehow less worthy of advancing despite their stellar early game teamwork, objective focus and otherwise?

I agree that 1 player does not make enough of a difference, you need to be lucky enough to get that 1 or 2 extra people on your team that want to try, and do. Otherwise I don't even think a Korean challenger could carry themselves out of bronze at any better rate than your average player on bronze OCE.

The reality I find is, just play solo, get good at Jungle so you can support whatever lane is winning, push that lane right in early, force the other lanes to split and allow the other lanes on your team to farm (whether they lost lane or not, they will gain/regain their lost advantage). Or similarly a mid lane roamer who can push other lanes as well.
It's hard to carry as a top laner unless you get insanely fed (well, generic tanky top laner, you can pull it off as Quinn or similar, but you aren't tanky enough and often enough top is the only tanky champ in low elo).

I suppose you could take the same philosophy as supp, do your best to get your adc kills and push lane, and otherwise help mid and try to press a bigger advantage and ward up drag/their jungle so your jungler can see when theirs is there/low hp/not in their top, etc..
But I find it a lot harder to make big impact plays as a supp in that situation, especially if top is the one who is winning and your lanes despite all your effort are just feeding or whatever.
late game impact you're obviously going to be more valuable as supp, especially Thresh, but most games are won/lost in 5-10 minutes in low elo, people give up and cry themselves into a losing mindset by then. Early tower downs really hurt bronze morale, thus why I prefer jungle to carry myself out of things.


Ironically enough this season (I started on NA, xfered recently), I went 8/2 in my promos, I was S4 last season (my first season, I was green as hell at the start and destroyed my MMR early on, only gave it a quick go at the end of the season and got to S4), those 8 wins were 50% domination, by me as jungler (shyv, entirely), 50% also surrenders by them, all B2-S4 players, and the system placed me in Bronze 3, go figure right?
Got myself to Silver 5 before I xfered about a week ago, and did my single placement match on OCE, guess where it put me? you may have guessed it! Bronze 3 =D, yay.

Honestly, support is one of the easier roles to carry from if you know what you're doing. 90% of the time the enemy bot lane (the support especially) will only be playing that role because they were last pick and will have no idea what they're doing, so it's incredibly easy to win lane even if your ADC is useless. The bot lane with the better support almost always wins lane, especially if you are significantly better than your opponent. Its also a morale thing, think of how many times you've seen "gg noob bot lane" or similar. This can be the enemy team in nearly every game. A support carries in the laning phase and in the mid game with vision and roaming, by then you can have a big lead for your team and be heavily favoured to win.

Other tips i would give to make carrying easier:

-Once you win lane (which you should do 90% of the time, since the enemy bot lane will usually suck), translate this into an advantage for the rest of your team. You DO NOT need to follow the ADC around all game, especially since they will often have no idea where they need to be on the map. Around the time you hit level 6 (sometimes even before) you should be looking for opportunities to roam. Good times for this are when you push up to enemy turret or your ADC goes back to base. Also look to get wards in the bot side of the enemy jungle to open up opportunities to gank their jungler. If you get a kill or force bot lane to back, or get a kill while roaming mid, get dragon if your jungler is in the area and your not too low. This may require several pings before your team will cooperate. Once it gets to mid game, you should rarely be in bot lane anymore.

-If you lose lane, roam. Staying in lane doing nothing and/or dying will not get your team an advantage. Go gank mid or top to try get yourself back into the game and give your team an advantage. Return to lane in time to prevent your ADC getting tower dived if possible. 

-Try to assess the relative power/skill of the other people as the game progresses. You should be trying to work with and protect the teammates that have the highest chance of carrying the game. If your ADC sucks, theres no point peeling for him when you could be protecting your 5-0 mid laner instead. Similarly, try to see which enemies are most likely to carry the game and use you cc effectively to stop them killing your whole team.

-Buy pink wards constantly and upgrade your sweeper as soon as you get level 9. People in bronze facecheck bushes constantly and you can snowball super hard in the mid game by clearing wards and catching people. Once you have an advatage look to keep at least one side of their jungle warded up and clear any wards you see them place in this area for easy catches.

-Stop playing thresh. However good you might think you are, I can basically guarantee you could do better with a less complicated champion. Thresh isn't just about landing hooks, there are a lot more things to factor into your decision making than with a more simple support. He also requires a greater degree of competence from your teammates (clicking lanterns, providing damage on the people you cc) which you cannot expect in bronze. AP supports with cc and  burst are the best in my experience, because its easy to catch people out and get kills with little to no help from your team and you can snowball easily by yourself. Stuff like Annie, Morgana, Brand. Tankier supports like Blitzcrank or Leona are somewhat less effective but also good.

-Take ignite instead of exhaust. This will make it easier to punish people for mistakes in lane and snowball a lead. Also helps to secure kills mid game while ganking or if you catch low health enemies. The only time i would recommend taking exhaust is if they have multiple late game exhaust targets (assassins, high dps bruisers) that your teamcomp cannot otherwise deal with.

He pretty much summed it up.
Yes thresh can make fancy plays but as ^above^ said, he's far more team reliant and his CC ain't as hard as other supports.
His AP support recommendations are accurate but I'd personally add zyra, lux and lissandra into the mix. They're much less supporty but if your on a loosing streak and wanna enter super ultra try hard mode, these may do it for ya. As for tanks, nautilus has re-entered the scene(which is highly unfortunate as I'm no longer the one playing the rarely seen champ) and braum are extremely powerful peel supports if that's what your team needs.

To add, I find that support, mid and jungle. Have the greatest influence on your teams actions. Learn how and when to call the shots like when to group, take dragons, baron ect. This skill alone(well and basic aim, wards ect) carried me and naut(jg) out of bronze as I ruled my teams with an iron fist! You don't listen to me, guess what? my team goes off at you, whole team don't listen to me? then ah well sh*t happens. Be assertive. But don't be a total pain in the ass. Nagging the jungle or mid who are just warding to be safe, to htfu will only aggravate the situation. Not only can you make yourself the czar and tell people when and what the team should be doing, but also control conflict. Not many do it but calming the mid laner who just died due to a countergank(now blaming and BMing jungler) down, instead of letting his keyboard run wild can really help the team. As this makes the player under attack feel better that someone has his back, puts the twat in his place and the rest of the team usually goes(literally had someone say this 2 days ago) "thanks heavens we have someone with some sense of maturity" and in that game my team continued to listen and we continued onto victory.

I've carried myself from Bronze 5 with 0 LP to I think I was Bronze 2 today with 90 LP. I've had a couple of bad games and lost my momentum but I have all the confidence that I will manage to keep progressing.

I also don't think someone that mains support could automatically pick up mid mechanics and own face with them. I like playing support because I'm familiar with 90% of the mechanics that I come across so I have more control over my game and how it turns out.

I'd personally be playing supports with a good amount of damage output; something like Fiddlesticks, Brand or Lulu.

All of those champions do what they do without farm, and can easily convert to a more AP-centric build if you get ahead.

You should definitely not be neglecting your vision control duties if you play damage-centric supports, though, or you might find that a lack of vision control allows your enemy to flank you easily or bait you into a trap.

Yes, but you are playing League in hard mode. Support is probably the hardest role to carry from.

You always have the same build. Gotta change it depending on the enemy team comp and your own.
You always build Face of the Mountain - Sunfire Cape - Randuins - Warmogs... why? Even against double AP comps you never build MR. You never build a MIkaels to save your ADCs.
You also seem to NEVER buy Pink wards {{item:2043}}  extremely useful and powerful item.

Also why do you max Flay first? The standard is R-Q-W-E on Thresh. E-Q-W-Q-Q-R etc...

Duo is the easiest way to get yourself out. Doesn't have to be a friend. You don't even need to voice chat. Just add an ADC you play with in a game who you think played well or you have good synergy with and ask them if they want to duo.

But i'd say you have to learn more about the game yourself before you start climbing.

Back when i mained thresh i maxed flay first over hook, reasoning is your looking for a lot of auto harass, it can win you lane without landing a hook so that when you can land the opening hook, your looking at an easy kill.

And honestly the cons are minimal, sure you won't be able to hook as often, but the aim is to hook well, not often.

Since they added the flat 3 second refund on landing hooks maxing q first has become pretty standard, sometimes with 2-3 points in e for laning. Having q maxed by the time mid-game comes around means you can usually get 2-3 hooks off in a teamfight

Honestly, maxing your lantern over anything else is how I always played him. The shield and cooldown is invaluable compared to the utility from his Q and the damage from his E. You shouldn't need to max Q for damage or cooldown. Landing it reduces the cooldown as it is and your ADC should have the damage to follow up by the time you E and ult (if necessary) anyway. Just my two cents, that's how I've always played and I played him to B1 Promos into Silver 5 back in S3. I'd be considering items like Zeke's as well.

I would say you can, but it might take more than what you already done. You will need to help gank for mid and still be able to protect your carry. You might learn how to rotate well between lane. Ward control is what really need if you want your team not dying. 1 more, learn how to call for objectives, that's important in any role and help a lot. Also play careful, do not need for any highlight, once you land a good hook, that's highlight already.

It's slightly easier to carry as AD than support, wherein if your support is bad its not as punishing as if your ADC is bad - but bear in mind ADC is pretty easy whereas support is high stress because you have  a lot to do and a lot to think about so if you are really good it's actually easier to win games as a good support than a good adc because a good support can shut down your entire team.
its not about how many hooks you hit. its about which hooks you hit. :^)

You can escape gold+ with support but probably not bronze. Bronze is the league of, "I'm better than my team and I deserve challenger and I make no mistakes." Bronze people will probably always blame the support so yeah just play another role imo
